intro: Gonzalagunia tacanensis, commonly known as the Tacana thistle, is a flowering plant native to the high Andean regions of Bolivia. It is characterized by its spiny, glandular leaves and purple to pinkish flowers that bloom in late summer. The plant belongs to the Asteraceae family, which includes daisies and sunflowers, and is adapted to the cool, high-altitude climate of its habitat. Its structure includes a thick, woody stem and basal leaves that are often covered in fine hairs. Gonzalagunia tacanensis plays a minor role in local ecosystems but is of interest to botanists due to its unique morphology and restricted distribution.
